item.title: A new wave of analyzers in .NET8
item.description: Analyzers did become an integral part of the .NET ecosystem. Their main responsibility is to find potential code issues and warn you. Often times this comes even with potential fixes you can directly apply. And Microsoft will continue this journey with the upcoming .NET 8 release. This blog post will show you potential candidates, which will make the cut.

item.title: Episode 46: Vim - with Joseph Woodward
item.description: In this episode, I was joined again by Joseph Woodward to geek out on Vim! Joe joined us on the last episode to talk about the Go programming language - and as we’re both huge fans of Vim, we decided to stay on and record a second episode chatting about it! In it, we talk about both the Vim way of using the keyboard (Vim keybindings), and also Vim the editor and its plugin ecosystem.
item.author: (Dan Clarke)

item.title: I/O is no longer the bottleneck
item.description: In 2022, disk I/O is very fast, and not usually the performance bottleneck in programs. This article digs into some numbers.
item.author: (Ben Hoyt)

item.title: Azure SQL Trigger for Azure Functions in Public Preview
item.description: Azure recently announced the public preview of Azure SQL trigger for Azure Functions to build event-driven applications. The new functionality is currently available only for C# functions and can be triggered by changes to an Azure SQL table.
item.author: (Renato Losio)

item.title: Developing Applications in Space with Azure Orbital Space SDK
item.description: Microsoft recently announced the preview release of the Azure Orbital Space SDK to provide developers with a secure hosting platform and application toolkit designed to enable them to create, deploy, and operate applications on-orbit.
item.author:
(Steef-Jan Wiggers
Cloud Queue Lead EditorFollow)

item.title: Cybersecurity Grads Should Consider Consulting - Andrew Katz
item.description: The Problem Too many times, I have heard this plea from college grads on /r/cybersecurity and LinkedIn: “My BS in Cybersecurity didn’t teach me useful skills, and I can’t find a job.” These grads are faced with the beaten-to-death conundrum: you need experience to get experience. On top of that, there are applicants with a few years under their belt to compete against for these jobs. Unless you know someone or convince a hiring manager to take a chance on you, getting an entry-level, in-house cybersecurity job without experience is exceedingly difficult.

item.title: Twitter, ActivityPub and The Future
item.description: Twitter is - was - such a unique place. Somewhere where you can have the President of the United States coexist with teenagers writing fan fiction; where celebrities give personal insights into their lives while government departments post memes about public safety; the place that gave us @Horse_ebooks and @dril.
